reviewText:
I don't play Hidden Object games, but this one seemed interesting.  I believe I was initially attracted to the art, so I decided to purchase this on sale and give it a try.  The game starts out very well and I was quickly addicted.  I played five hours straight, beat the game, and obtained all the achievements.  I thoroughly enjoyed this experience; however I do have a couple gripes.  I feel like the developers simply gave up as they designed the last level.  The last level is essentially re-used, and extremely easy compared to previous levels.  Also, the game ends all too abruptly and leaves you scratching your head.

Being relatively new to this genre, I started on Casual.  I quickly found that the game was too easy, so I bumped it up to Expert.  If you’re not playing on Expert, your map will be marked with places that you have available actions.  This pretty much tells you exactly where you need to go, so I suggest you play on Expert from the start.

Overall, I enjoyed this game.  It is the first Hidden Object/Puzzle game I have actually completed.  For its current sale price, it is worth picking up if you’re a fan of the genre.
voteText: 57 of 64 people (89%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
** Key was provided by developer for review purposes	**

Mind Snares: Alice's Journey
Mind Snares: Alice's Journey is a fun point and click, hidden object, adventure game. The puzzles are interesting, the art is good, and the overall story is interesting. I will add a TL;DR at the end.

Gameplay
The game focuses on allowing you to follow a story more than anything. The controls are simple, all you do it use your mouse to progress through the game. The game is a decent length and allows you to enjoy it thoroughly before giving you an ending. In the game you will explore, collect items in your inventory, play mini-games, and find objects. You will be going from one area to the next utilizing the items you have collected to move forward in the story.
The story is fairly short in my opinion and the ending felt incomplete. This is a game that focuses more on telling a story and allowing one to relax as they adventure. The hidden object parts of the game are fun and enjoyable and each of the mini-games was different and fun to beat. As a point and click game it’s very well thought out and does well on capturing the story and allowing for a relaxing experience.

Graphics/Sound
The graphics of the game are polished and very well done. The cinematic scenes are ok in my opinion. Each area you visit the art is great and some of the art can even be breathtaking. The voice acting is alright and the music is relaxing. The graphics and sound were good in helping to create a relaxing atmosphere.

Pros/Cons
Pros

+ Excellent Art
+ Solid Story
+ Different places show different aspects of life and how we live it
+ Relaxing experience
+ Interesting Concept
+ Fun puzzles
+ Diary to review what happened and find your current objective

Cons

- Ending felt incomplete
- Nothing was really explained in the end (how Alice got here/ if she is alright after driving off the edge)
- Limited replayability

Final thoughts
It's been a long time since I have played a hidden object game or a point and click game. I am happy to say I enjoyed Mind Snares: Alice's Journey. The art was amazing, the music was good, the story was interesting, and the little lessons I saw were nice. The ending bugged me a bit and it just felt incomplete. However overall I enjoyed playing through the game from start to finish and it was nice to return to a hidden object point and click type of game.

TL;DR
Mind Snares: Alice's Journey is a point and click hidden object type game. The art is done well and the graphics are beautiful. The music is alright and the voice acting is adequate. The game is well-designed and very enjoyable and quite relaxing to play through. The ending felt incomplete in my opinion and there is limited replayability. The puzzles and mini-games were fun to beat and the game was fun from start to finish.  Overall if you are a fan of hidden object, point and click, or just games that have an interesting story , then Mind Snares: Alice's Journey may be a game for you.

If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

reviewText:
Neutral Rating

I'm honestly not too sure about this one. I found the Story to be interesting, yet rather bland for my liking. At the start of the 2nd Chapter I started to feel more attuned to it, but then shortly after it just dropped off again.

The Puzzles were moderate, I didn't get stuck on any of them and some did make me think a bit more than others, but nothing complicated.

The Hidden Object Scenes seemed rather pointless most of the time. I really couldn't see any connection with the items I had to search for, to the item I recieved afterwards. As this is only my second HOG I have played, I'm not sure if this follows the traditional ways of Mechanics or not. Either way, they are still nice to do, and can be very relaxing.

The Art style was nice, and the Music was ok. I felt that the Voice Acting was overdone in parts, but it was acceptable.

The Ending was a bit of a let down to me. It just didn't feel finished. Instead of leaving me with a sense of accomplishment with having everything in it's right place, I was left with a sense of disappointment.

I don't think the Game was bad at all, but I just felt that it could have been polished a bit better in certain area's.

Genre
- Hidden Object / Adventure

Game Elements
- Hidden Object
- Puzzle

Average Playthrough
- 3.5 Hours

Liked
- Nice Puzzles
- Great Art style

Disliked
- Found it hard to get into the Story
- Pretty poor Ending

reviewText:
Once again a great hidden object game from Artifex Mundi.

This time you are Alice with a broken mind trying to figure out what happened last night. You had a car crash.. falling through glass.. what is with this red electric in your veins?!

Pros
A great plot. It's a really good story and well worth finishing it.
Pretty visuals. Nice art with cool coloring.
Good puzzels that are fun to play through. You won't to hit the skip button all the time.

Cons
It's easy, even if you play at it's hardest level.
It's short. Less than 3 hours per play though.

So if you enjoy hidden object games. This is a good one, if a little easy and short. It has been made well, it's fun, and it's nice to watch. Worth picking up.

reviewText: Without giving too much away, this is a game any working soul who has been in the same job for say over a year can relate to.  The concept is solid as well as the storyline which is meant for a more mature minded audience.  The gamer can literally hear the tiredness" in Alice's voice.\n\nStory: Since this game begins with the epilogue
date: the storyline is actually about when (and probably even why) Alice decided to become the owner and proprietor of her own business.  During the interview Alice relates how she worked in a job she hated (or in my opinion was tired of being taken advantage of by her boss).  She always wanted to start her own business but was afraid to (with good reason if one understands how hard that really is and the risk involved.)  Two years prior to the game beginning
recommended: late one evening (workaholic) before her vacation with her family was about to begin her insensitive boss sent her to an out of town business meeting. On the way to the meeting Alice is in an accident.  This is the beginning of her journey.  She wakes up in an alternate place (most likely her own mind) and must find her way back.\n\nGameplay: The journey takes place over 5 chapters
hoursPlayed: with the epilogue beginning the story and introducing the dark shadowy man who appears throughout the game as a quasi-nemesis.  The first chapter begins the journey and sets up the other four chapters which are separate "adventures".  Each chapter segment has its own goal
voteText: its own gather and use inventory and its own map making gameplay easy since there is no crossover between the chapter area and the "outside".  Each area must be completed before progressing to the next chapter.  The storyline concept plays out as each chapter is completed and is not overly "preachy".  This game could be considered to have a psychcological suspense/horror theme since no place is scary then inside one's own head.  Each area has its own terror theme.  I really liked Chapter 3 - Baba Yaga.  Seldom is the most notorious and terrifying witch Baba Yaga (and her chicken hut) ever seen in HOs and the designers added to it what I can only call that bayou zombie ambience making the whole area subtly terrifying.  Not that the other chapters did not have their own subtle terror.\n\nHidden Object scenes:  The Hidden Object scenes are fitting to the area they are found in and basically not piles of random "junk" found in random places.  They are uncluttered for the most part and the find clues are relatively easy to locate
helpfulPercent: except for one or two that either blend well into the background or are so obvious they get overlooked.  There are also "extra step" find clues such pouring wine in a glass for glass of wine
votesHelpful: or striking a match to lit a candle for lit candle.   Overall not a huge challenge but challenging enough to not be considered too easy.\n\nPuzzles: Believe it or not the puzzles were theme oriented and the type found depended on the chapter theme.  Overall the variety was excellent and included mechanical
column17: matching and "follow the recipe/design/blueprint" puzzles.\n\nThe point and click aspect of the game was about equal with hidden object aspect
column18:
and quite the challenge at times when trying to figure out what to do or where something was located.  Some of the achievements reflect both the humor and creative thinking of some of the point and click challenges.  Some say games never teach anyone anything so I wonder how many gamers had to look up 'hew' and  'decoction' to know what to do?

Just a few comments to end this review.
1) I wish the developers would have closed the game with a tiny short wrap up cutscene of ending the interview. Something as simple as "And that is when/why/how I decided to start my own business" over a handshake or something.  It would have added the proverbial "cherry on top."
2) Watch the credits.  It is not very often anyone in any media takes the time to make credits interesting.  I found all the X-rays amusing and unique
column19: especially the one of the Artifex Mundi logo.\n3) All Steam achievements can be completed in a single play through
column20: which is always a blessing since I dislike forced second playthrough for achievements.  I for one am also glad to see achievements in-game or steam finally moving away from "solve x in x amount of time" and becoming more creative.\n4 and the last) There is a fast travel map
column21: not that it is really needed.  No forced second playthrough (usually meaning on expert/advanced
column22: and often with Artifex Mundi games the alternative "game" to the Hidden Object scene).  No extra "hidden/shifting/ghost" objects to find.  No penalties for map use
column23: game hints (not to be confused with HO scene or puzzle hints)

reviewText:
Short version: 80%Mind Snares is another nice piece of Artifex Mundi hidden object game craftsmanship, with a non-conventional story of self-discovery and good progress design. The puzzles needed a little more polish tough.

Long version:Mind Snares: Alice’s Journey is an odd modern hidden object game, where the protagonist is just a normal everyday office worker called Alice Dahl, who doesn’t have to find a kidnapped relative, save the world from some mysterious dark entity, or investigate some weird occult site. She is just an average woman who suffers a car crash and traverses through her own mind to find her inner strength to face the hardships of her life, like her job slowly distancing her from her family.

Her self-discovering journey is divided into four segments with their own themes (steampunk factory, fairy tale forest, witch’s hut, and phantom hospital). This story structure left little room for backtracking, but also cut the game short, where most of the play time is spent on the rather uninspired, mediocre hidden object scenes. They aren’t bad, but they also held back the final score, which could have been much higher just for this story alone.
voteText: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText: These Artifex Mundi HOGs are the gaming equivalent of comfort food. When I fire one up I know exactly what to expect and I can mindlessly click through them as a way to wind down after work. After the eleven billionth title I've started to get sick of seeing the same puzzles: the concentric rings, the recipe for a potion, the safe combination, and so forth. I want Artifex Mundi to take a few risks and try something a bit different.\n\nAlthough Mind Snares follows the formula pretty closely, it does take a few risks by abandoning the usual supernatural theme in favour of a psychological inner journey. And instead of the usual abandoned child that needs saving, Alice is saving office workers from their demeaning jobs. So big ups for trying something a bit different.

reviewText:
How come I've never review that excellent game?

You're Alice and you're explaining your story: you was in an accident and you wake up in a strange place. In order to escape, you have to travel into different dimensions...

It's one of these games published by Artifex Mundi that could have been developed by them: the plot, while easy to figure, is magnificient in terms of travels, the graphics are beautiful and dark at the same time and the soundtrack is as usual fitting.

The gameplay is the usual one: hidden objects scenes (not too easy and not tpp hard), puzzles (not too hard) and exploring to find useful items (the best thing). For once, the translation is polished - I'll probably be always very aware of that since another game that had german and italian words for a French translation.

If anything, this game is a must-have. Don't hesitate if you're a lover of casual gaming or HOG!

reviewText: There are good hidden object games and bad hidden object games, Mind Snare: Alice's Journey is a great hidden object game.  The puzzles are varied, the hidden object scenes run from simple to hard to find objects that are perfectly hidden, the graphics are wonderful and the storyline is worthy of paying attention to.  Here you follow a character named Alice is trying to free her mind of the evils that reside in it.  I haven't seen any mention, but I believe that this parallels the Alice in Wonderland main character who may have fallen too deeply in the rabbit hole and is trying to get her mind put back together.  Each chapter completed heals a part of her mind until it is completely healed.\n\nNot much more to say other than if you're interested in these types of games, then it would a disfavor for you not to play this game.  It is exactly what every other hidden object game should aspire to be like.  I definitely recommend this game.

reviewText:
Too short to recommend, especially at full price.  It's a very simple HOG from Artifex Mundi, one of their simplest with the barest amount of achievements.  It's not a bad game, and might be worth picking up on sale for a buck or two.  Beyond that, the game is just too short and too simplistic to recommend.

And perhaps the worst part is that the story is not even fleshed out.  It's minimal to begin with, but then ends without explaining or resolving itself.  This game just feels half-hearted from start to finish, and feels more like a demo that stills needs some tweaking to really be able to call it a finished game.  It's not buggy, and the production quality is fine for what it is... it just needs more story development, some more meat on its bones, and an actual ending.

4/10

reviewText: This is one of Artifex's Hidden Object Games, and I can say it is a good one. However, it is a bit short for my tastes. Most other Hidden Object Games have taken 4-6 hours for me to finish (maybe more if I want to play it through a second time). I will still recomend it as long as it goes on sale for half the price. I can't justify spending $9.99 on this game. Perhaps $2.99-$3.99.\n\nStill I enjoyed it and will still recommend it... if it is on sale.

reviewText:
This is a pretty well done hidden object game that builds up a good atmosphere and has a good (if unsubtle) plot/theme of someone deciding to start their own business during a moment of crisis (presumably she nust run this successful new business alone, having no employees, because otherwise she in turn would be CRUSHING THEIR DREAMS!).

The gameplay is good - there are a lot of puzzles with a good variety, although they all tend towards easy (or even trivial in some cases), the hidden object scenes are nice and clear without any problems I remember, and the point and click stuff that glues it all together is pretty clear and logical, and everything fits together pretty well.

The game is short, but only really in line with many others in the genre, and there is little replayability here (and no forced replaying needed purely for achievements, unlike some other similar games), but you can probably pick it up fairly cheap for what amounts to an evenings entertainment, so I don't think that is a particularly problematic thing, so it is fairly easy to recommend as significantly better than average for the genre.

reviewText:
This is a nice point-and-click game by Artiflex. They are my favorite producers in this kind of game since they created the Grim Legends series. Strongly recommended!

As always, the graphics and the style of the game is quite impressive. Although the history isn't very good on this one, it's a bit cliche: a woman who works too much and because of that loses her family and is transported for a strange place where she has to conquer 4 symbols to get back home.

This is a short game, the achievements are very easy to get and the puzzles and hidden objects scenes are very good.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Time til 100% Game Completion Without Hints/Skips: 2.3hours

A short but nice game. It's a very dark toned inside your head kind of game. While I can't say the area/story flows well the gameplay itself is good. Very fluid puzzles and for the most part logical item usage making hints not really needed. That being said 2.3 hours is not a lot of game play so I can only reccomend picking this game up if you get it in a bundle, on it's own even on sale it's not worth it. The graphic quality while not as HD as some of Artifex Mundi's newest games, is still good quality.

Story SPOILERS: You start off giving an interview about your book store and learn Alice was working at a job with a horrible boss who made her work long hours and miss out on important family events. On a drive to a location the boss couldn't make it so you had to fill in for, a sudden bolt of lighting strikes and you drive off the edge of a cliff. Sunddely you're inside your mind and battling a ghostly demon. The story never explains who/what it is or what anything in your mind is really. You see a picture that Alice said she drew as a child of her and her mother and this demon near thier house but that would imply she's lived with it her whole life? A woman is trapped in a tree that helps you but then she dies about 80% way through the game. Things just seem to happen and places you go dont seem to represent anything, they're just pretty. While yes one area is her workaholic spirit and another is her inner balance, it just seems like small aspects were taken and tossed together.

End of Spoilers

Overall if you're looking for a creepy hidden object game this game delivers, if you're looking for one with a good story, look else where and don't look here unless it's in a bundle!

reviewText:
While this isn't the best of Artifex Mundi, it's still heads and shoulders above many other hidden-object games, and I recommend it for lovers of the genre.

The storyline is straightforward but takes you through a few very different words. The graphics and music are as terrific. There's a decent amount of content: quite a bit of point-and-click adventuring, several (fairly easy) hidden-object scenes, and (medium-low difficulty) puzzle mini-games. It's a casual, nice way to spend a couple of hours -- as long as you know what to expect.

Where the game falters is in the clunky text (at least in English), and in some lazy animations.

Best line: YOU SAVED THE LITTLE PUMPKINS AND ARE VERY COMPASSIONATE." Yes

reviewText:
The game is just bad compared to the other Artifex Mundi games. (Well, the developer of this game is not Artifex Mundi themself as usual.) I highly suggest that you skip this one and play the other Artifex Mundi games. If you do not agree with my review, comments are appreciated.

The good:
+The graphics are good as usual.
+Four different themes/chapters.

The bad:
-Don't expect to see good stories here. They are just puzzle-placers.
-There are only a few types of mini games you can play.
-It's not the collector's edtion, so you won't get the extra content, or replay the puzzles w/o starting a story.
-Almost everything is worse than the other Artifex Mundi games.

reviewText:
The option menu has two sections: one is for the volume controls and the other one is for the miscellaneous options. In the volume control section: music, sound and voice overs; separate adjustments. In the miscellaneous section: Game Difficulty, Custom Cursor, Full Screen and Aspect Ratio (this option only works if you play the game in full screen mode.)

The game’s difficulty menu has three options, Casual; Advanced and Expert, for you to choose from. The game’s difficulty can be adjusted in the middle of game play.

There isn’t much to say about the game’s voiceovers/music/sounds asides from that they are well done.

There isn’t much to say about the game’s graphics aside from that they are nicely drawn with a bit of painted feel to it. It kind of reminds me of Artifex Mundi’s graphics.

Most of the cinematic scenes throughout the entire game can be skip. The skip function is usually located at the top or the bottom of the screen.

Diary Notebook has been sectioned off into two. One section is for all the game’s objects and the second section is for all the game’s clues/story. Keeps the diary notebook in order but one minor downside, the clue section doesn’t stay opened, each time you access the diary notebook to look at the clues.

Inventory Panel has the option for you to keep it lock in place or unlock to have it hidden from view. Easy access to the items that are collected throughout the game. Some items have “x” amount that required before using; the image changes when an item added to it.

Hybrid interactive hidden object scenes: traditional word lists most with find “x” amount of an item

Most of the puzzles are rather simple to solve but while others would some and/or little extra necessarily steps to solve them completely; puzzles with a puzzle. There’s no reset button for the puzzles, with exception of one puzzle, but there’s a skip button for the puzzles.

Game achievements are earned throughout the entire game. The achievement menu can be access through the game menu or through the option menu on the main after the loading screen.

There’s an interactive map but it won’t show up until the first chapter of the game starts. The key legend on map explains the function each of the map icon. Fast travel from one location to another and back.

The game has an automatic save function, it saves whenever you exit to the game’s main menu, you can continue where you left off in the game.

There are four chapters in total but the length of the game depends how quickly the individual plays the game.

There are seventeen game achievements. Most of these achievements do come with some requirements before they can be unlock completely.

reviewText:
This is a solid Hidden Object game. This company produces many of the good games in this genre. If you are looking for a challenge I definitely recommend playing on the hardest difficulty level. For all of you HO fans I will warn you that this game is 50% puzzle and 50% HO at most. The nice thing is, not only are you given no hints, the puzzles themselves are more difficult version of the same task.  The artwork is good, the story is a little weak but OK and the HO clues and screens are clear. The only small issue I had is that the game is a bit short and sometimes I ended up exiting out of screens by accident because the back out option takes up too much of the bottom of the screen.

All in all worth playing especially if you can get it on discount.

reviewText: NICE GAME

reviewText:
Another quality HO/puzzle game from Artifex Mundi.  I generally expect their offerings to be good and I wasn't disappointed here.

First off, I was pretty delighted to see a story go beyond the basic fairy tale or creepy story to actually give a message, and an important one at that.  It was beautifully handled and not overdone.

Sound and music were good quality with voice acting that actually sounded like they put some effort into it.  This is, as always, a huge plus for me personally although I know other people aren't bothered by bad voiceovers like I am.

Hidden object scenes are nicely done and properly challenging (ranging towards the easy side of the spectrum) without any weird naming issues; if it tells you to look for an apple, you're going to find an apple.  This isn't always the case with these games so it's a plus for me.

Puzzles are essentially your usual fare for this style of game, variations on the normal variety you'll always see, but they are nicely done and graphically pretty, and I enjoyed myself.

Play time runs about three hours, which is average for this style of game.  My play time is longer as I was letting the game sit here and there to get some other things done.  Three hours is a pretty normal run time for these games, but I always feel that ten bucks is a little spendy for this kind of game.  Personally, I would wait for a half-off or better sale or coupon first unless money is no concern or you're used to picking these up at full price.  It's certainly worth a playthrough.

reviewText:
I always feel these style games are overlooked by many, and its a shame because they are quite engrossing. Mind Snares: Alice’s Journey is a mature adventure game that blends together elements of the surreal, psychological thriller, and horror genres.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=45PJlegHiJI

Alice’s car breaks down and plunges into a river. The next thing she knows, she wakes up in a strange world made of her own memories, dreams and nightmares. Ruling over this bizarre dream land is the mysterious Shadow, who forces the protagonist to face her deepest fears.
In order to escape this ominous, psychedelic world, Alice needs to follow an enigmatic lifeline and locate four magical totems that will allow her to rebuild a bridge back to her own reality. But this proves to be no easy task. Alice must venture deep inside her own subconscious, to face motley characters embodying friendly as well as hostile parts of her own psyche.

Alice solves charades and puzzle that test her intellectual prowess. She must confront the ghosts from her past, suddenly made real by the Shadow’s insidious power.
Will our protagonist muster the strength to defeat her own demons? Or will the Shadow win? The fate of Alice lies in your hands! -  Recommended!

reviewText:
I love games that Artifex Mundi publishes, but this one intrigued me more than most. The story was actually remarkably good for a hidden object game, voice acting was superb, and the puzzles were challenging without being infuriating. The hand-painted graphics are up to the usual quality that I expect from modern hidden object games, and the music always felt appropriate.

I also appreciated that the Steam Achievements were not designed to artificially increase the difficulty, extend gameplay by trying to make you play the hardest level, or force a second run-through with that alternate-puzzle scheme that Artifex Mundi sometimes employs. All of the achievements can be done in one play through regardless of the difficulty level.

If I have any complaint, it would be that the ending is too abrupt. The game is actually a flashback to a story that is being relayed to a newspaper reporter; but when the ending is reached, the game goes right into the credits. There is no satisfactory resolution to explain why the story took place, nor was there any kind of cutscene in the present to close out the interview. Was it all a dream/nightmare? Was it a halluicination? Was she really magically deleported to some alternate reality? Maybe there is a sequel in the works; but if there's not, the ending leaves much to be desired.

The game can be completed in less than three hours, so the normal price might be a bit high for some. Those who equate value with the length of time it takes to play a game might want to pick this up on a Steam sale or a 3rd party bundle/indie site.

Regardless of the ending or the (potentially) short game time, this is one of the better hidden object games out there and it worthy of your time.

reviewText:
You play Alice, a young women, now successful, but it wasn't always like that.
She recalls how her journey started, 2 years ago in a dead end job...
She was abused by her boss and instead of leaving for her vacation she needed to meet a client in Seattle, because her boss couldn't make it, again.
She has a car crash on the way there. She wakes up in a creepy hospital room, with a creepy hooded man.

This is where you get started.
You need to get out of there and back to your husband and daughter, but the hooded man keeps putting obstacles in your way, or is he.
As you accomplish different tasks, chapters and save or help others, you realize that this hooded man is in fact your subconscious and you are battling with yourself.

I had a lot of fun.
The story is rich, full of puzzles, hidden object and task to accomplish.
I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
As a huge HOG and Artifex Mundi fan, I must say that you won't be disappointed about this game. It knows everything it should: point&click, story, mini-games, hidden objects and astonishing graphics.

If it's your first HOG, maybe your first Artifex Mundi game, you'll surely love it. I've played every Artifex Mundi game except one and I'd like to see something new in these games. Story changes, OK. Still, they use the very same recipe for every game and it's getting a little bit boring. As far as I can tell we've seen all the mini-games (with different textures) in other AM games!

Chapter 1's story was outstanding, but the rest of it seemed just too basic after that. Buy it if you can!

4 chapters with finding the items you need to proceed and taking down riddles in your path in order to escape your fate of imprisonment in a realm of darkness.

First time I played a point-and-click game and i impressed withthe work they put it.

Pros:

+Amazing music
+Easy Achievements

Cons:

-Found it to be too short (after finishing it once, I was able to clear it again in 30 minutes)
-Ending a bit anti-climactic

All in all it was a nice game. I bought it with a sale coupon, and I suggest you do the same.
If you are an achievement hunter, this series of point-and -click games can give you some really easy games to complete.

6.5/10

reviewText:
Overall this is a typically well-done hidden object adventure from Artifex Mundi.

It's better than a lot of HOGs, but it's not the strongest game from this studio.

The plot sees main character Alice, a dissatisfied office drone, fighting her way through a fantasy world in order to learn how to have confidence in herself and her dreams. As usual for an Artifex game, the art is lovely and vivid, and the puzzles and minigames are solid and well-designed.

The ending is a bit abrupt, and strangely the game begins by revealing that Alice went on to start her own successful business, with the whole game as a sort of flashback explaining how she got the gumption to strike out on her own. That takes some of the suspense (such as it is) out of the story. And to be honest, I would have been happy to just solve the puzzles and explore the fantasy vistas without the framing narrative of Alice's stifling job and her journey toward self-confidence.

Still, can't fault them for trying something different, I guess.

I'd recommend a number of Artifex games ahead of this one. Dark Arcana: The Carnival is a favorite, with a strong story and striking visuals, and Grim Legends 2: Song of the Dark Swan is one of their most compelling and well-made titles. But if you've played those, and the Nightmares from the Deep series, and Enigmatis and Abyss... then I'd also recommend Mind Snares.

reviewText:
Ongoing review notes for Mind Snares: Alice's Journey...

- lovely graphics

- the music is getting tedious after an hour. It tries to stay dramatic the whole time, and that just isn't working. Dramatic only works in conjunction with non-dramatic. (Update: each chapter seems to have its own soundtrack, and that only applied to the first chapter.)

- nice environments and some intriguing interactions here. Only one of the interactions has made me ask, WTF was that?" but afterwards i had to admit that it kinda made sense.

- the Damsel in Distress (DiD) vibe is truly creepy. Frustratingly so. i don't
voteText: enjoy the DiD trope except in the context of the "Empowered" comic book series (which exists to poke fun at that trope).\n\n- the protagonist's repeated self-derision just helps drives the DiD vibe home. It's hard to tell if she's supposed to be a victim or a hero
helpfulPercent: and victimized women is _not_ a theme i care to game.\n\n- all the little female dolls (in many of the scenes)
votesHelpful: most of them looking like sad
votesFunny: is bringing me down. Not sure how much more of that i can take. (Update: they disappear after completing the factory level.)\n\ni like the mechanics
column16: but i truly, deeply, dislike the whole DiD/victim/poor-little-me bit. The physics have a slighly different feel from the 10 or 12 (or so) Atrifex Mundi titles i've played so far, and they developers have done really well with it. The dark victim/DiD tone is making it painful for me to keep up with, though. It's creepy, and not in a fun-creepy kinda way, but more in the, that man's been staring at that little girl for far too long" kinda creepy.\n\ni'm still undecided but i'm going to give it a Thumb Up because it is
column18:
nicely done and a pleasure to play. It's just the tone and thematic elements i'm having trouble accepting as being something i want to play through.

Update: creepy in the extreme. Whoever scripted this is seriously screwed in the head.

Update: after the first chapter
column19: the DiD/victim vibe drops off to essentially zero. That's a good thing. After that point (specifically
column20: after existing the factory) It retains much of its abstract weirdness but drops the creepy imagery/theme."

reviewText:
This is my review of Mind Snares: Alice Journey.

I was on ♥♥♥ and found out that they would sell random Steam keys for quite cheap. Me and My Associate thought it would be funny to purchase one and play the game, no matter how bad it looked. This is the product of that experience, and I have to say that We were very pleasantly surprised.

From the outside, this doesn't look like the most appealing game in the world. We thought that it would be kind of naff and a bit dull. The gameplay can be described as straight forward Point and Click Puzzler with Elements of Where's Wally. The art really grows on you and has the same type of charm that you would find in Alice: Madness Returns (It's not only the name that they share in common.)

The plot isn't the strongest point of this game, but it works as the carriage to help understand the setting and gameplay elements. The gaming formula does become quite tiresome towards the end of Alice's Journey, but there is still fun to be had. I would recommend that you give this game a shot at least once, and We shall be trying out some of the creators other games in the future.

Remember Dear Readers, You heard it here first. Off the record, On the QT, and very, Hush-Hush.
